name: phosphonic acid, 1,2-ethanediylbis-
Reason: 1,2-ethanediylbisphosphonic acid has a melting point that we will compare to ethane, which has a melting point of -172.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be ethane, which has a melting point of -172.0 degrees Celsius. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 1,2-ethanediylbisphosphonic acid, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the phosphonic acid group introduces a carbonyl functional group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point. The net effect should thus be a significant increase in melting point due to both the additional phenyl rings and the carbonyl functional group.
